content: Sometime between this 10 am and 3 pm today, @Melva Peters edited all the FHIR Shorthand issues that were formerly "submitted" changed them to "triaged". Is there a way to revert that action? Now I have lost track of which issues have really been triaged, and which haven't.

Triaged is a function that Melva normally does for all issues - Work groups aren't expected to look at non-triaged items (and in many cases, the work group isn't even assigned). Work-group-specific triage is generally handled by filling in 'grouping' (ready-for-vote, fit-for-teleconference, etc.)

There's no way to go back to Submitted from Triaged because all that Triaged means is that the issue has a work group filled in and seems to be expressed in a sufficiently coherent way that a work group could resolve it. (If the latter test fails, it gets assigned back to the submitter for clarification).
That makes no sense to me. Now I don't know which issues I have read and which I haven't.
That's not what Triaged was ever for
(Same process was used when we were in gForge for 3+ years
How do you define "triage"? I guess in HL7 it means something other than "put into high, medium, and low priority groups"
Nevertheless, given that they are all triaged, how can I tell which issues don't have suggested resolutions?
It means ensure that the issue is appropriately categorized and is ready for WG resolution (proper issue type, proper project, proper artifact categorization, work group assigned)
I guess it is always dangerous to assume that words mean the same thing in HL7 as in the rest of the world.

Triage: the assigning of priority order to projects on the basis of where funds and other resources can be best used, are most needed, or are most likely to achieve success
HL7 "triage" : ensure that the issue is appropriately categorized and is ready for WG resolution (proper issue type, proper project, proper artifact categorization, work group assigned)
It's the word and definition that's been in place since FHIR started using Jira and this is the first time anyone's had an issue...
